name: Kare Kare
description: Enjoy this authentic Kare Kare recipe for Filipino oxtail stew in a delicious peanut sauce. This popular dish is prepared on special occasions like birthdays and family gatherings. For a boost of flavor, serve it with a fermented shrimp paste called bagoong.
recipeIngredient: ¼ cup annatto seeds ((soaked in ½ cup boiling water))

recipeInstructions.text: To a pot, add neutral oil and sauté 1 red onions (diced) and 1 whole garlic (minced). When the onions turn translucent, remove the onions and garlic to a plate and set aside.
recipeInstructions.name: To a pot, add neutral oil and sauté 1 red onions (diced) and 1 whole garlic (minced). When the onions turn translucent, remove the onions and garlic to a plate and set aside.

recipeInstructions.text: Using the same pot, add 2.2 lbs oxtails and brown them on all sides.
recipeInstructions.name: Using the same pot, add 2.2 lbs oxtails and brown them on all sides.

recipeInstructions.text: Add the sautéed onion and garlic back to the pot. Then, pour 4 cups beef stock/broth and 1 cup water into the pot. Bring to a boil, cover, and simmer for 1½ hours or until the meat is tender (add more water if needed).
recipeInstructions.name: Add the sautéed onion and garlic back to the pot. Then, pour 4 cups beef stock/broth and 1 cup water into the pot. Bring to a boil, cover, and simmer for 1½ hours or until the meat is tender (add more water if needed).

recipeInstructions.text: Turn of the heat. Remove the oxtail from the pot, leaving all the liquid, and set the oxtail aside.
recipeInstructions.name: Turn of the heat. Remove the oxtail from the pot, leaving all the liquid, and set the oxtail aside.

recipeInstructions.text: Add 3 Tbsp brown sugar, ¼ cup ground toasted rice, 1 cup unsalted peanut butter, and the water from soaking ¼ cup annatto seeds into the pot. Mix thoroughly until it’s even in consistency. Turn on the heat to medium, then let it boil.
recipeInstructions.name: Add 3 Tbsp brown sugar, ¼ cup ground toasted rice, 1 cup unsalted peanut butter, and the water from soaking ¼ cup annatto seeds into the pot. Mix thoroughly until it’s even in consistency. Turn on the heat to medium, then let it boil.

recipeInstructions.text: Once the sauce is boiling, turn the heat to low. Add the oxtail and simmer for 15 minutes. Season with a dash of Diamond Crystal kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper.
recipeInstructions.name: Once the sauce is boiling, turn the heat to low. Add the oxtail and simmer for 15 minutes. Season with a dash of Diamond Crystal kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper.

recipeInstructions.text: Now, cook the vegetables separately by blanching 1 bundle string beans, 3 pieces eggplant, and 1 bunch baby bok choy.
recipeInstructions.name: Now, cook the vegetables separately by blanching 1 bundle string beans, 3 pieces eggplant, and 1 bunch baby bok choy.

recipeInstructions.text: Pour the stew into individual deep bowls and add the cooked vegetables on the side. Serve with bagoong (fermented shrimp paste).
recipeInstructions.name: Pour the stew into individual deep bowls and add the cooked vegetables on the side. Serve with bagoong (fermented shrimp paste).

review.reviewBody: In your history of the dish, you omitted the REAL origins of it. It came from the Sepoys from India bright by the British when they shortly colonized the Philippines in the 18th century. The Sepoys made curry using local ingredients.
